Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2008 08:38PM heatherpalmerton wrote: Hi Eileen, I have been on taxotere since Jan 08. I will say my first 2 treatments didn't go so well. I fell into that 2% of being allergic to Taxotere.  My ONC and staff have been so wonderful.  They thought I would have to stop that treatment.  I said "no" we would continue. I felt this was going to work.  So they started me on premeds. Plenty of steroids, benydril, lots of liquids and they allways have administered it very slow at the beginning.  I  have this  3wks on 1 wk off  and zometa 1x a month. Treatment has gone very well for me. I do drink alot of water,tea and fresh lemon. so far all blood work is great and even better on some. Thursdays are usually my tired day and I like to take naps. When I get my Zometa is when I get a little aching. But have found if I keep moving I'm not as stiff and sore. Eileen I also have scleroderma, just a suggestion, with your joints bothering you.  Have you had an ANA test done. On one of the other threads we talked about how many breast cancer patients had autoimmune diseases. I hope the very best for you and that your pain goes away soon. Heather

Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2008 08:59AM heatherpalmerton wrote: I Have said this many times that 40 is not the magic number for a mammogram. I have seen to many young women under forty that are getting breast cancer and being dx with stage 4 at the time of original dx. Ins companies need to be more informed and allow more early mammos/us. Went to chemo yesterday and mentioned something similar to my nurse. She did tell me that if you are in the high risk for breast cancer, ins will pay for it. Also learned that Christina Applegate was just dx'd with breast cancer. they caught it very early do to her proactive approach. Her mom was a cancer patient, if I remember that article correctly her mother passed away do to breast cancer. Christina would have her mammo once a year then 6 months later have a US. I truly hope the best for her and that she does well with her treatment. I have talk to several women in our area that have had these gene test and have come back positive for the the gene. The have optided for breast removal and reconsrtuction. I know it was a very personal choice. At least they do get a choice unlike so many women in the past.  Women with very dense breast, They have been doing a breast MRI with a dye in our area. Seems to be finding if there are any problems.

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2010 04:58AM - edited Apr 27, 2010 05:04AM by heatherpalmerton I saw that on bcmets they have a link I will try to connect with it. But i too have a hard time doing this. So if someone comes earlier to post it, It would be great. I guess I could try to copy and paste. hear i go i'll try to paste article. This is too good to just post the link--Musa April 26, 2010 The New York Times 17 Years Later, Stage 4 Survivor Is Savoring a Life Well Lived By KATHERINE RUSSELL RICH Each year on a day in January � the 15th, to be precise � I go to a Web site and post a message to hundreds of women I�ve never met, saying, essentially, �I�m still here.� Within days, a thunderous chorus comes back, 200 voices, 300. A few of them ask, �How can this be?� Sometimes they begin, �I�m crying.� Many answer in kind: �I�m here, too. It�s now three years.� �Five years.� �Three months.� �Seven.� What we�re doing, in a way, is checking for lights in the darkness. Now there probably aren�t a lot of Web sites where the announcement that you�re around and breathing would cause anyone to take notice, let alone respond. But this is a site for people with Stage 4 breast cancer, something I�ve had for 17 years. The average life expectancy with the diagnosis is 30 months, so this is a little like saying I�m 172 years old: seemingly impossible. But it�s not. I first found I had the illness in 1988, and it was rediagnosed as Stage 4 in 1993. That�s 22 years all together, which is the reason I post each year on the anniversary of the day I learned my cancer was back: to let women know that it happens, that people do live with this for years. I tell them that when the cancer returned, it came on so fast, spread so quickly, that I was given a year or two to live. Within months, the disease turned vicious. It started breaking bones from within, and was coming close to severing my spinal cord. Nothing was working, till a doctor tried a hormone treatment no one used much anymore, and the cancer turned and retreated, snarling. It remains sluggish but active. Every so often, it rears its head; when it does, we switch treatments and it slides back down. In that way, I stay alive. I tell them: you just don�t know. Two and a half years after the Stage 4 diagnosis, I confessed to my mother that the doctors had said I had two years to live, tops. I�d kept this information to myself because if you say it, it�s true. I told her this laughing, as if we were trading preposterous stories. �Well, I guess you�re going to have to hold your breath if you�re going to make that deadline,� she replied, in her slow Southern drawl when I gave my previously stated expiration date. I spent the next five years holding my breath, then did the same for another five. I enacted every New Year�s resolution, past and future, all at once. Quit work that had grown stale and became a writer. Wrote a book. Went to India on assignment, fell in love with the language that was swirling around me, went back to live for a year and learn Hindi. Didn�t realize the reason I�d come to dislike that hyperbolically overachieving Lance Armstrong was that his behavior was too familiar. Take a nap, Lance! I�d think to myself, though in truth I couldn�t either. But if I was verging on radical levels of life consumption, I had a reason: No one had told me I wasn�t going to die soon. About 12 years out, my doctor finally did. There�s a small subcategory of people with Stage 4 breast cancer, it turned out, who live for years and years. �Twenty. Thirty,� said my doctor, George Raptis. This group constitutes about 2 percent of all cases. Doctors can�t predict who will fall into this category. They can�t say you�re in it till you�re in it � till you�ve racked up the necessary miles. The reason they can�t is that for all the pink-ribbon hoopla, despite the hundreds of millions that have been poured into breast cancer research, hardly anyone has looked into the why of long-distance survival; not one doctor has specialized in this field. Here�s pretty much the sum of collective knowledge: People in this group tend to have disease that has spread to the bone (as opposed to lung or liver, say) and feeds on estrogen. They tend to do well on hormone treatments. End of commonly known story. But as Dr. Gabriel N. Hortobagyi at M.D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston told me, you can also find women whose breast cancer spread to organs other than bone, for whom hormone therapy did exactly nothing, who had their lesions surgically excised and who have been free of cancer for 30 years. None of these women could have expected to live. You just don�t know, and neither, unfortunately, does the medical field. One reason, as the breast surgeon Dr. Susan Love told me, is that �many clinical trials are funded by the drug companies to run for five years,� obviously not enough if you�re investigating long-term survivors. But through her institute, the Dr. Susan Love Research Foundation, she has begun to conduct research. Dr. Love said she was inspired by a colleague who told her that in World War II, aviation experts focused on planes that went down until someone said, �Why aren�t we studying the planes that stay up in the air?� By no means a reflexive optimist, she thinks there�s hope we�ll find a cure. On the Web site, I tell the women how deeply I believe there�s no such thing as false hope: all hope is valid, even for people like us, even when hope would no longer appear to be sensible. Life itself isn�t sensible, I say. No one can say with ultimate authority what will happen � with cancer, with a job that appears shaky, with all reversed fortunes � so you may as well seize all glimmers that appear. I write to them (to myself) that of course this is tough: the waiting to see if the shadows are multiplying, the physical pain, the bouts with terrible blackness. �But there can be joy in this life, too,� I say, �and that�s so important to remember. This disease does not invalidate us. This past year, I�ve had the joy of falling in love with my sister�s kids, who live states away and whom I hadn�t had the chance to know. I�ve had a second book come out, one I worked on for eight years, about going to live in India with Stage 4 cancer. I�ve had so many moments of joy this year, but when I�m in blackness, I forget about those.� Then I ask them to write and tell me about theirs, and lights begin to flash. �Had a pajama party with my oldest friend, laughing through the night in matching pajamas about old times.� �Came in second in a bridge tournament.� �I went on a wonderful camping trip with my family.� �Seeing my older daughter grow taller than me. She�s now 5-9.� One thing I don�t ever think to say: When I was told I had a year or two, I didn�t want anything one might expect: no blow-out trip to the Galápagos, no perfect meal at Alain Ducasse, no defiant red Maserati. All I wanted was ordinary life back, for ordinary life, it became utterly clear, is more valuable than anything else. I don�t think to say it, and I never will. The women on the site already know that. Katherine Russell Rich is the author of �Dreaming in Hindi: Coming Awake in Another Language� and �The Red Devil: To Hell With Cancer � and Back.� -------------------------------------------------------------------- mail2web.com

Also the fact that there are alot of women that become so knowledgable by the research they have personally done and when they bring it to the table it makes us more aware.  I know that I wish I would have been hear at my first DX. Oh how I would have done things so differently.  Konakat You are truly a sweet heart and what ever you are feeling "It is okay" I admire your honesty.  For me I get so many peolpe that come into my store that are not even cancer victims, they give me so much strength. What I get tired of is the people that are just plain ignorant. Then I just have to educate them. For those men and women who are not stage 4 I challenge you to do something positive in finding a cure. Yes I think awareness is important. I do not want any of you to go through what we go through.  There has been alot of talk about susan b komen not aknowleging stage4 pt.  Just remember anyone that is not stage 4 can be just like the rest of us that are.  Sorry so long winded but I had to say something.  If it comes across negative. I truly do not meen for it to be that way, Heather

What away to be woke up that early in the morning. Well come to find out. It is over a boy, Oh what to do??? My eldest started to date a young man, who has a phsyco ex GF. After last night we got a taste of her brattiness,  kids these days are quite braison about what they write on texts.  Come to find out her dad is a local cop and has been throwing that into other girls faces that she will beat them up if they come close to her BF. "This poor boy can't even get away from her."  she also tells the girls that her dad is a cop no one can do anything to her. sounds like she needs a little whoop a*##.  It sounds like one of those teeneage stories on lifetime "CRAZY"...... I'll keep pushing what my mother allways told me as a child and into adulthood, Kill them with kindness. LuAnn, I remember those days, My hair was so thick that if  I put it into a pony and up after a shower My hair would still be wet at the end of the day. Thats how my girls hair is now. It was so funny, "Well I have to laugh", My oldest daughters  hair was about down to her waist. Her hair is so thick that when she played soccer she was ask to tuck it up because she would hurt people with her tail. when she found out that i was going to have chemo. she went down and had it cut just below her ears, "Really cute" I must say" She was so excited she thought she would be able to have a wig made for me. We were excited for her, she had done something so sweet. Then we find out I wasnt losing my hair, just thinning. you should of seen the look on her face. She would have like to have held me down and shaved my head.  We still laugh about that one. I told her just to hang on to it. maybe we  could give it to love for locks.  Oh Yes got a bit sidetracked, The girls did enjoy themselves. Ashley's guy friend showed up with his mom at the dinner house gave both my daughters roses and bought their dinners, now that was really sweet. thanks fo all the support, Heather
Posts.Title: Help I need your motherly advice heatherpalmerton heatherpalmerton

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2009 02:38PM heatherpalmerton wrote: Cheryl, I am so very sorry that your going through this, even though I haven't had the chemo your on. I have dealt with some of the stuff your going through. relaxation: I reccomend a nice champagne or tea bubble bath. place candles around the bathroom and tub. Put on some good music. turn down the lights relax and sip away. (for some really good bubbles use MR. BUBBLE) constipation: Hurts like hell, plain and simple. There was a time when I was so packed with poo. My husband would hold on to me because i couldn't sit on the toilet because of all the open wounds on my butt (from scleroderma). It was like giving birth with no repreave, no rewards. We tried the supositories only for them to fly back at my husband. I was to embarrased to go to the ER so my husband put on the ole rubber gloves  and lots of vaseline and began to extract these things you could have used to make a brick house. Wouldn't reccomend that but it was releif at the time. relief: when i feel that i maybe getting a little constipated I make up whole oats oatmeal, cream of wheat, snack on prunes, lots of water with lemon and tea If It gets to bad Drinking a glass of epson salt and water Just be by a toilet 45 min from the time you swallow your last swallow. driving: does your town have a senior and disabilty program?? our transit service does, they have free or minimul charge  where they come to your house and pick up and take you to your appts or grocery shopping. It worked really great when I needed it. nausea: does your onc give you anything for that? I know my onc did even if i felt i didn't need it. they just wanted to be sure I didn't go through that. venting; vent away, vent away, vent away!!! It's ok we are here to listen. Janis yes I agree with you about screaming. I used to do that with my girls when i was really sick with the scleroderma. Boy was it invigorating and empowering. So I say scream away.  Cheryl sending you many gentle hugs, Heather

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2010 04:23PM heatherpalmerton wrote: Judii, Thank you for your post. As allways very uplifting. We just do not know what our journey will be . I was supposed to be dead in 1998/99 Due to my scleroderma. I have superceded my life expectency in the scleroderma world by 11 yrs. Believe you me I look at at past pictures (very few) I looked like  I had one foot in the grave and one dangling close by. I made a descision at that time that I wasn't ready to die, I just didn't feel it. I even had one dr tell my husband I wasn't going home. PROVED HIM WRONG!!! I Fired him. I decided that I still had alot of life. I wanted my kids to know if I did die. I wasn't going down with out a fight. I wanted them to be aware of these diseases. But mostly I wasn't going to let this disease take my attitude, my spunk or my determination. It just would not take me down that way. I try to live my life to the best I can. I do have melt downs. Thats okay. I just know that I will continue to go on. try to make a differnce in someone elses life. I saw that you are triple neg. With the research i have looked into they are addressing triple negs  and aiming for more treatments. I also find that knowledge is power and you will find alot of that hear. I send you many gentle hugs. Heather

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2008 05:48AM heatherpalmerton wrote: Hi Deb c, It really ticks me off about these ins companies, how do they justify putting these caps when they are dealing with our lives. Or when you have a treatment plan that has been working and all of a sudden they say it isnt a medical necessity. That happened to me a few years back. because of my scleroderma (contractures, stiffness the gammit of the disease) I religously went to physical therapy then this lovely little guy with the title "MD" sent me a letter stating i was not to have physical therapy that is was not deemed a (medical necessity) Well we got even. My Drs and PTS wrote letters. One of the ladies at my husband work (Vernice) The head Colonels wrote letters just that one file was about two inches thick with all the support. Then the real clincher was Vernice had my husband take pictures of me practically naked. Oh my lord I must of scared the living daylights right of that man Mr MD.  It wasnt long before I had a letter aplogizing for the misunderstang.  Not only that we found out the man that wrote the letter was not a (MD - Medical Doctor) He was only a medical director. I think thats what really ticked me off. He probably had no idea what this disease was really about. So its been over ten years and im still going to physical therapy. I also now have medicare even at the age of 42 I pay for it through my social security disability. Which has been a good thing.  Deb, In regards to your question I havent had to deal with that because I have medicare and tricare remote(military) but i will check with my Onc billing dept and hospital see what i can find out. Heather

Posts.Content: May 16, 2009 10:55PM heatherpalmerton wrote: I have felt that way in the past. I do feel at times it can be overkill "pardon the pun" for the pink ribbon awareness.  Yes awareness and being your own advocate is so very important. I don't want anyone to go through what we have or have been. I just want them to find that damn cure. "sooner than later."  I will say that I enjoy What safeway does with there fund raising and  asking customers to donate their change.  With doing research allot of that money goes strictly in finding a cure for this beast.  Not just the  awareness part of it.  When I'm finished I will post various web sites where you can see where that money goes to finding a cure.  Patti i guess i see it so differently only because I have been dealing with a terminal illness for such a long time. So for me I say "I'm a breast cancer survivor surviving mets".  About keeping things normal.  We keep it as much as possible. My daughters sometimes ask if things would be different if I hadn't got sick from scleroderma. I sad yes I would be that very mean strict mother that wouldn't let anything slide at all.  "oh MOM" They say.  Yes it has sucked big time at times, We have found so much ro appreciate.  One question that my youngest daughter had ask was "how come you have to tell everyone about our life" referring to my two diseases.  I said because people want to hear especially after being in the newspaper several times.  I was doing a fund raiser at Safeway.   My youngest daughter was with me and several other people. I was standing there talking to people.  I had a man and two sons come up and talk to me about his wife and cancer. What she was going through and how difficult it was. He wanted to know how I was dealing with it. We talked about so much. It was so neat because my daughter had seen how I had helped this man and two sons.  "she said mom now i know why you talk about your illnesses." I also told her how it reallu helped me.  It was such a light bulb moment for her.  Patti I also feel support is a personal comfort and how ever one chosen to do so. that is up to that person. Thats why I get on here because the support is so GREAT.  I also love working at Safeway. I have so many customers that come in to bless me, hug me and just to check on me to see how I'm doing. It gives me more strength, a feeling to fight like no other.  sorry so long winded Heather

Well the ultimate word is tried' when your body is calcified and you have contractures, of the knees, ankles, hips, fingers and elbows you try to get into these great positions that are really awesome for you "BUT" for me, it's not the best idea. Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2008 11:56PM heatherpalmerton wrote: SPEAKING FROM EXPERIENCE........ There is allways HOPE. If I had listened to my lung DR I would of been dead 11 years ago. (from scleroderma) Then I was DX 2002 breast cancer. later I learned that they didn't have much hope in my survival because I was so ill from the scleroderma. january 2008 I was DX with stage 4 mets to the bones, liver. I started Taxotere, fell into the 2% of being allergic to it. Yes Had a very bad reaction. that happened two times. With Zometa and premeds (steroids) I managed to have my treatment that I insisted to continue after ONC was thinking I would have to stop. I said NO I will continue. Anyways. I had my 3 month scans. to our amazement the scans came out so awesome. Onc quite stunned. When we saw the comparisons from Jan scans (Which my husband said I looked like a christmas tree lite up). This past Monday I got my results from my recent scans and yes they were awesome again. So now I'll go on femara and be off chemo.   As you have  seen there are alot of neat and great women on these boards that are full of wonderful information.  They have helped me in so many ways.  I feel with positive attitude, keeping your mind busy with the things that you enjoy, lots of faith and spiritual from within. and yes knowing there is hope. I wiil put your sister on our prayer list. Heather

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2008 11:34PM - edited Apr 10, 2008 08:02AM by heatherpalmerton Hi luckywife, First thing first, It's okay to be scared, but speaking from experience please don't ever give up, We and especially me need you here for wisdom and all your wonderful insight. Yes it sucks to use a wheel chair i have used a manual and electric wheelchair and boy howdy I can give you some stories. But first I will give you some pointers. Some of these have been mentioned but i want suggest them again, Occupational therapy and physical therapy has been a big part of my life. Even when i was enduring pain that i did with my disease. i continued PT. For me it was a good pain because I knew it was going to go away and i believed in my heart it was doing me good and eventually it got  me out of the chair. several years later but it did. With occupational therapy they came into my house and did an evaluation of everything i needed to better my life. it was amazing what things there are.   They can but these hand rail bars in every position to aid you to go to the bathroom, shower, shower chairs. when my strength was better I used a walker. also the raised toilet seat, one other thing i didn't have to use but was reccomended was they can have this thing installed from your bedroom ceiling that you can hold onto and its helps you get to your chair. now that i'm talking about this i really suggest Occupational Therapy, They were really helpful. Luckywife, I want you to remember this you are a fighter you have proven this to me. I would love to send you the articles they did on me about the scleroderma. if you are interested please send your address. It will show the pain I endured and how so many postive people came into my life and how postive prayer, thoughts can get us through anything. That being said I am sending you a great big virtual hug and lots of postive thoughts and prayers your way. Heather

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2008 11:36PM heatherpalmerton wrote: Hi Michelle, im so sorry your mom is going through this. but the good side is, she has you helping her. I hope the best for you both and when she has her scans they will all be good.  I havent had this experience do to chemo. But i have with the scleroderma, its a very scary feeling to be choking I dont do it near as much as I used to but when i was at sickest, my esophogus was so week and so very sore i really couldnt swallow. I would choke when I tried to eat. My family would make me something to eat, they would cut whatever into very tiny bites and my two little girls at the time would say "momma you can do this" what helped was having a big glass of liquid to help swallow the food down. that sure made it easier. Something else I would do that helped to keep nutrients in my body, just because i wasnt eating the portions i surely needed. My husband and kids would make 5000 calorie shakes, smoothies, I used a straw for those, then i could get it far enough to the back of my throat and it was easier to swallow.  I hope maybe that could help your mom untill you can get into the Dr. I hope the best for you and mom Heather

Posts.Content: May 25, 2009 01:01PM - edited May 25, 2009 01:03PM by heatherpalmerton After reading these post, Why does it seem to be mostly adults, being so insensitive. I must say for me it hasn't happened to much. But it does. I had a mother, daughter and boyfriend come into Safeway looking for flowers, she was kinda arrogant anyways. She treated me like I didn't know a darn thing.  I went into the cooler to get something for her and  as I was walking out I saw that she was mocking me how I walked. I was so stunned and lost for words. Her daughter was so embarresed, which she should have been. (I charged her for every little thing that there was to be charged for, things that she thought she would get for free).  For the most part I confront them, "do you have any questions, I'll be more than happy to help answer any that you may have" It also helps that I work in such a public place "Safeway" I also have other issues I have contractures in my fingers really bad. So it really surprise people that I can even design.  I had a teeneage young man. Very sweet ask me what was wrong with my fingers and how did I manage to make flower arrangements. I explained to him, he was totally amazed.   "I always tell that person thank you for being honest and never be afraid to ask questions.  He has been a great customer ever since.  What I love most "Is how children can be so honest in asking there questions"

You are going through rough patch, I know you will get through this. you are strong and with all of us we will see you through!!! LuAnn, When my health was such despare, I was 88lbs and bed ridden, couldn't go to the bathroom, take showers, my husband carried me everywhere,shower, S#%T, & shine, I couldn't even wipe my BUTT,I really had to rely on my kids and husband. then after 4 years of this I came up with ways to use back scratchers. As far as trying to eat and keep my strength I know truly this did help. We tried a lot of things. What we found that, what worked best for me to maintain my weight was a weight building product from albertson's, I would buy chocolate and vanilla flavors (easier to mix fun stuff into) the mix was like 5000 calorie to start. Then my kids would add, varies fruits, ice cream, wheatgerm, at the age of 6 and ten they had so much fun. Even if i couldn't drink it all I knew I was getting sustainable calories. This was something very important to. Yes it hurt, It hurt like hella bad. My philosophy was no pain no gain. I kept in my mind that the pain I was induring while they were working on me was a good pain, because that pain was going to make the bad pain feel like it wasn't so bad. I know this is totally different from what your going through, I share this with you, so you know there are various options and physical theripst are trained to help people individually. Also do you have any aids to help you, a walker, shower chair, toilet chair, wheel chair. these are things that can be borrowed from various orginizations, walmart or costco has these items at reasonable prices. Sending you a very TL virtual hugs Heather

Posts.Content: Feb 29, 2008 08:55AM heatherpalmerton wrote: Hello ladies, I too have a autoimmune disease "scleroderma" CREST I have had this for almost 10 years. It began with fatique, losing all my hair. going form 156lbs to 88lbs in less than four months, into the hospital with fibrosis of the lungs you could literaly push on my chest and i sounded like the little plastic bubbles we like to pop.  I had a open door at the emergency room. with needing antibotics for celluitis. The calinosis was so bad that it would literaly explode.even though i was ridden for almost 4 years with my husband carrying me where ever i needed to be. when a dr told me I needed to go home and get my affairs in order that gave me more determination to live. We lived our lives as best we new we could. never giving up. even though i was in the most escruciating pain i continue to go to physical therapy. it was a good pain it went away. with my family dr she supported me in any decision or idea that we had. we tried chealation, the hyperbaric chamber. alot of these things worked and with out trying them we would not have known. so with that "try any and everything". to make long story short.  Then i was dx with breast cancer. because i was already so sick i just really went with the flow. but the chemo i belive put me in a better spot at that time. I began to get stronger, eating foods with flavor. it allowed me to get enough strength to get a electric wheel chair and boy was i the cats meow. it gave me a new sense of indendence.. fall of 2006 went to floral design school and now im working at safeway floral. sorry Ill have to return its time to take my daughter to school. if any of you have questions please ask im an open book hugs and prayers Heather

It reminds me of when my younger sister  and I would be laying in bed in the winter bundled in our home made quilts from my grandma We lived in a a home that was over 100 years old. The insulation was not the best. I was so cold that we could see our breath. We would lay there clattering our teeth. We came up with ideaa to pass the time before we went to sleep. Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2009 05:46PM heatherpalmerton wrote: KLynn, These diets maybe really good, I just found that we could not afford them. So what I did for my husband is that we switched to using salad plates. So it really looks like he's getting alot of food. We were think about gastric bypass for him and went to several of their support group. Met with dieticians.  The key way of thinking for us was using a good source of protien,  grilled chicken, lean meats (all with out Hormones or added antibiotics) Using less salt. vegitables and fruit and then very little carbs.  I know that it doesn't sound like alot but when we started to eat less food with out all the crap we were feeling very full and we didn't have to eat as much. It has been so much healthier for me too.  Also I will drink alot of water and tea with lemon. makes you feel so much fuller.  I will also make a snack of smoked gouda cheese with apple and various other stuff. I make things very simple. Excercise has been good. I know this will soung crazy but I find when I do exercise i have more energy.  I hope the very best for yoy in what ever you chose to do, Heather

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2008 09:17PM - edited Mar 9, 2008 09:23PM by heatherpalmerton Pearl, im sorry to hear your sons are having a hard time.  It is hard.I think more so for boys to see there mothers ill. at least it was for my brothers when my mother was ill.  For my kids Ashley  18 and Mckenzie  15  They have allready delt with so much in the past ten years . Living with a chronic illness has become the norm for them. When they were younger we all went to counciling more so for my oldest she had alot of anger issues. we have come along ways. They saw a young mother who was very active, volunteered at school, camping, going to the coast, water skiing, hiking we used to play in the yard. then they saw their mother deteriate so fast allmost to nothing. we dealt with the closeness of death for so long about four years before i was dx with breast cancer. i managed to get through chemo. I felt like it had saved my life. It was amazing I started to gain weight again, I started to get my taste back. One day I woke up and didnt have to take pain meds.What was the most amazing thing was before I was dx with breast cancer. our local paper did a article about me and scleroderma. I went into safeway all i was going to get was a roasted chicken. It literally took me over two hours to get out of there. I had so many people stop to talk, pray, hug me I had the the most bizarre experience happen to me. there was a lady she ask if she could hug me said a little prayer kissed me on the forhead and said you are an angel you will be all right. The feeling that over came me took over my whole body. it was the most awesome feeling. So i truly believe i have made it this far by the grace of God.    I have been somewhat open to my kids about this dx only because my oldest is a SR and has so much on her plate. they know I have cancer but Mack notice i was on the computer reading a comment .about the 3 day walk. She was exited to see it. macks aunt and all hear friends are planning to walk in seattle  summer of 2009 they will be 16 then.  she notice stage 4 she wanted to know what stage I was I told her. she looked surprised. I said it was okay. Many women live with stage 4.  It was going to be like living with scleroderma and remember the dr told us i was going to die ten years ago. Why im going through chemo is to put it back into remission. its called dancing with NED. She laughed and said okay. So when are we going shopping? Thats teenage girls for you.  Pearl I hope the best for you Hugs and prayers  Heather

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2008 01:31PM - edited Sep 10, 2008 01:33PM by heatherpalmerton My youngest daughter asked me today if I was going to the volleyball game that one of the seniors in the past had started as a senior project. It was to recognize breast cancer awareness and one of our local support groups(which i supported in the past because when I was first dx'd in 2002 they were there bringing me a sweet little care package, they brought me bras and prosthesis?MS(FAKE BOOBS) This was very nice of them.  I went last year and all it was about was how they beat breast cancer and they were survivors. I thought this was great. BUT Now that I have been dx'd stage 4 It's like they don't want me in thier little group. I made a phone call to this little group. I kept getting a answering machine, finally got a phone call. I asked alot of question. at that point I really wanted to talk to someone who was stage 4. She told me someone from another county would call me back. NEVER got a phone call. I also was told where they were going to have a support meeting, went to show up and guess what?? no one was there. No phone call to say it was cancelled, nothing. I see all the fundraising they do in our communitee I see in there tight little shirts with BIG BOOBS so firmly sticking out there. I so badly wanted to lift up my shirt and show them my scar from the mastectomy.  Set up to let people know about thier group. I felt it was quite clickesh. This is only my opinion. I'm sure not everyone is like that in this group. So I said to my daughter I would love to go but I wanted to get a shirt that said "I'm a stage 4 breast cancer patient" and yes I'm SURVIVING"  I may just go down to our local shirt shop and get one. Heather
